Metlis, Matthew B. wrote:

> I view it more as adding a few extra lines of code to my tests than
> "jumping through hoops," but yes I would rather spend the extra time on
> my tests in order to keep my production code clean.

Matt, I appreciate your point of view, so I won't belabor the point; 
instead, I'll offer two observations.

1. Most of the methods I add "just for testing" are query methods 
without side effects, so they're generally not dangerous. If I'm /truly/ 
concerned about keeping methods hidden, I can hide classes behind 
interfaces, which tends to lead to more flexible designs, anyway.

2. Excessive complexity of any form is to be scrutinized carefully. If 
we must add complexity, I'd rather add less than more, and a query 
method is certainly less complex than circumventing a code privilege 
system that ought not to have been there in the first place.

It appears, though, that we've both done it both ways and that has led 
us to opposite conclusions. That's the kind of thing that makes life 
interesting enough to keep living.

Take care.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
